item.title: The Most Hilarious Medieval Combat Sim is Finally Entering Early Access Next Week
item.content:encoded:
Half Sword Games has finally unveiled an early access release date for its medieval combat simulator, Half Sword. The physics-based title emerged in October 2023 as a demo that turned (and impaled) heads very fast, almost entirely due to it being absolutely hilarious, in the worst way possible.

In Half Sword, you enter the arena against a range of opponents and use tricky, hard-to-master combat mechanics to slice, dice, crush, slash, slam, and impale your foes. It’s brutal, but the physics elements just make it an utter hoot to behold, and it’s finally entering early access on January 30.

Half Sword Hits Early Access on January 30

Half Sword’s demo was a roaring success, finding a social media and content niche that saw hilarious clips surface aplenty. The unique combat simulator focuses on being as realistic as possible while also being downright satirical. In one fight, you could be almost naked, windmilling your balled fists at enemies, and in another, you can be a knight in gleaming armor, decimating a group of peasants.

At the time of writing, more than 6,000 people were enjoying the Half Sword demo on Steam, and that’s with the test product representing a minuscule portion of the full potential of Half Sword Games’ first title.

To announce the impending early access launch, the team published a fantastic new trailer:

They followed this up with a disclaimer of sorts:

Bugs, performance, occasional crashes and other things are being actively ironed out as well as fast as our tiny team can handle.

There’s so much to love about Half Sword, but fair warning – the fiddly mechanics are not easy to master at all. It’s the kind of game where a single misstep can result in a total wipeout and the loss of progress, such is the game’s progression system, so you’d best be ready to potentially rage.

Are you looking forward to Half Sword’s early access launch? Let us know if you’ve enjoyed the demo on the Insider Gaming Discord server.

item.title: CONTROL Resonant Release Window Set for Q2 2026
item.content:encoded:
A release window has been set for the next game in the Control franchise.

At the 2025 Game Awards, Remedy Entertainment announced the sequel to CONTROL would be released in 2026. CONTROL Resonant is the follow-up game to the popular 2019 action-adventure game. Now, a clear release window for the next game has been confirmed: Remedy announced to investors in filings at the end of 2025 that Resonant would be released in the second quarter of 2026.

We are now waiting for the release of Control Resonant at the end of Q2’26 (was H1’27), which has significantly altered our revenue estimates for the coming years. Additionally, we had previously assumed that Annapurna’s share of the game’s sales would be outside of Remedy’s income statement, but it appears that this share will also flow through Remedy. Thus, our revenue estimates have increased accordingly, but Annapurna’s share is reflected as an expense in the income statement as well. Our net assumption regarding Control Resonant’s returns for Remedy over the first three years remains essentially unchanged. We now assume that Remedy will receive royalties from the Max Payne project only in 2027 (was Q4’26), even though the game may still be released in 2026. We estimate that Control Resonant will sell approximately 1.8 million copies in 2026 and approximately 2.2 million copies in 2027. Consequently, Remedy’s revenue is projected to surpass 120 MEUR in 2026–2027, with EBITDA reaching slightly over 20 MEUR. Conditions for strong game sales are favorable, as the original Control has sold over 5 million copies and has additionally been played by over 20 million players across various platforms.

More Information on CONTROL Resonant

A fictionalized Manhattan will be the setting for the open-world game. Fans will play as Dylan Faden and learn to control supernatural abilities with the promise that things will only get weirder as more information about the game is released.

Manhattan is at the peak of a paranatural crisis, the likes of which it has never seen, and the Federal Bureau of Control is running out of options. The FBC deploys Dylan Faden, their former captive, to take on a mysterious cosmic entity that is altering the fundamental aspects of our reality. As Dylan, you must harness your newfound supernatural abilities and take on a myriad of mind-bending threats.

Your fight will take you through multiple warped areas of Manhattan, allowing you to explore an unfamiliar world reshaped by a cosmic force that is defiling natural law, distorting gravity, and reordering Manhattan into a geophysical nightmare.

The CONTROL games also share the same universe as Alan Wake. The second game in the Alan Wake series has sold well over 2 million copies. Learn more about that here.

Insider Gaming will provide updates on the next CONTROL game as more information becomes available.

Are you excited for the next game in the CONTROL franchise? Sound off in our official Discord server. Also, don’t forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

item.title: EA Seeking Production Director for New Mass Effect
item.content:encoded:
A new job listing shows that Electronic Arts is laying the foundation for the next game in the Mass Effect series.

It has been the better part of a decade since the last release in the Mass Effect series, 2017’s Mass Effect: Andromeda. Now, EA has made a public move to secure the franchise’s direction. A new job listing from EA notes that the company is seeking a production director to serve as a leader on the next title in the game series.

EA is hoping the new Mass Effect Production Director has 10+ years of experience on AAA titles, deep ARPG and RPG knowledge, and proven team-building.

We are looking for a Production Director with a passion for the Mass Effect universe to serve as a high-impact leader on our next Mass Effect title. You will partner closely with creative leadership, studio teams, and internal and external partners to champion the game’s vision and ensure its execution at the highest quality bar.

The Current Direction of the Mass Effect IP

In November 2025, Mass Effect executive producer Mike Gamble proclaimed that EA and BioWare remain committed exclusively to the series and noted that there are more stories to tell in the universe. It has also been suggested that many believe the next title in the series will be a make-or-break moment for BioWare after the turbulent development of Dragon Age: The Veilguard.

There’s also a TV series in the works at Amazon. However, it has been confirmed that the series will not adapt the original game trilogy and will be an original story set after the events of the third game.
